title: Pouring — Pitcher to Four Cups with Sponging
description: The child pours water from a pitcher evenly into four small cups, then sponges any spills. This exercise refines estimation, control of movement, and introduces care of the environment.
instructions:
1. Place a tray with a small pitcher of water, four small cups, and a sponge.
2. Demonstrate pouring a small amount into each cup, going around twice to equalize.
3. Compare the water levels: 'Are all four the same?'
4. Show how to use the sponge to absorb spills and squeeze into a bowl.
5. Let the child practice independently.
6. Return all materials to the shelf when finished.

slides.heading: Pouring Water
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this fun activity we're going to do! We're going to practice pouring water from a big jug into four little cups. It's like being a super helpful grown-up!

slides.setup_instructions: Fill the pitcher about two-thirds full. Arrange four cups in a square on the tray.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all the cool things we need! We have a jug for pouring, four little cups to fill, a sponge for any little oopsies, a bowl, and a tray to keep everything tidy. Ask your grown-up to help you gather these special things!

slides.text: 'Today we have FOUR cups! The challenge is to make them all the same level.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Today, we have a special job for our four cups! The challenge is to see if we can fill them all up so the water is at the same spot in each one. It's like a little water guessing game!

slides.text: Pour a little into each cup: 1, 2, 3, 4. Go around again until the pitcher is empty.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's pour some water into our cups! We'll put a little bit in cup number one, then cup number two, then three, and then four. We'll go around one more time to make sure they all get a nice drink of water.

slides.text: Compare all four: 'Are they equal? Which needs more?' Adjust by pouring tiny amounts.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's look closely at our cups now. Can you see if the water is the same in all of them? If one cup needs a little more water, we can pour just a tiny, tiny bit more.

slides.text: Show sponging: press the sponge on any spill, lift it, squeeze it into the bowl. 'The sponge absorbs the water!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Uh oh, did a little water splash out? That's okay! Watch how we use this soft sponge – we just press it on the spill, and it drinks up all the water like magic! Then we squeeze it into the bowl.

slides.prompt: Practice pouring into four cups 3 times. Use the sponge to clean every drop. Can you keep the tray perfectly dry?
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the pouring expert! Try to fill all four cups so the water is just right, and use your sponge to clean up any little drips. Let's see if we can keep our tray super dry!

slides.text: Dry the tray, empty the cups, and return everything to the shelf. 'You poured into four cups evenly!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child pour approximately equal amounts into four cups and sponge independently?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, you did it! You poured the water so nicely into all four cups and kept everything so clean! You are such a super helper, and you learned how to pour like a pro!

parent_notes: Four cups increases the estimation challenge significantly. This naturally develops early division concepts — sharing equally. The sponging component teaches care of the environment, a key Practical Life category. Let the child practice as many times as they wish; each repetition builds concentration and refines motor control.
household_substitutes: Two small pitchers or measuring cups
Baking sheet or tray to catch spills
preparation_steps: Fill one pitcher halfway with water. Place both on a tray. Have sponge and towel ready.
control_of_error: The child can see if water spilled on the tray. The sponge teaches self-correction.
extension_ideas: Try pouring colored water to see it better
Advance to pouring into smaller cups
Pour dry rice or beans for a quieter version

title: Sandpaper Letters — i and Review
description: Introduction to sandpaper letter 'i' (short vowel as in 'igloo') and review of all learned letters: s, m, a, t, p, c, r, i.
instructions:
1. Present sandpaper letter 'i' (on blue background for vowel).
2. Trace while saying /i/ (short i, as in 'igloo'). Repeat 3 times.
3. Three-period lesson.
4. Review all 8 letters, mixing consonants and vowels.
5. Build new words with /i/: sit, rim, tip, rip, pit.
6. I Spy for /i/ objects: insect, igloo, inch.
materials_needed: All previously learned letters (s, m, a, t, p, c, r)

slides.heading: Sandpaper Letter
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this! Today we get to learn a new letter that makes a special sound. It's a vowel, like the 'a' we learned before, and it has a blue color to help us remember.

slides.setup_instructions: Place 'i' on the tray. Note the blue vowel background. Keep all review letters nearby.
slides.mascot_explanation: We need some special things to help us learn this new letter! We have our new sandpaper letter 'i' with its blue background. We also have the other letters we already know, and some little letter pieces to build words.

slides.text: 'Here is another vowel! Remember, vowels have the blue background.' Trace 'i': line down, then dot. Say /i/ as in igloo.
slides.mascot_explanation: See this letter? It's our new vowel, 'i'! It has a blue color because it's a vowel, just like 'a'. Let's trace it with our finger: down and then a little dot on top. Say /i/, like in 'igloo'!

slides.text: Child traces and says /i/. Three-period lesson: 'This says /i/.' 'Show me /i/.' 'What sound is this?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to feel the letter and make its sound! Trace the 'i' with your finger and say /i/. Can you show me the 'i' when I ask? And can you tell me its sound? You are so good at this!

slides.text: Review all 8 letters. Mix them up. Quick flash: hold up a letter, child says the sound.
slides.mascot_explanation: We are going to play a quick game with all the letters we know! I'll show you a letter super fast, and you tell me its sound. We know so many letters now; you're going to be amazing!

slides.text: New words with /i/: /s/-/i/-/t/ = sit! /r/-/i/-/p/ = rip! /t/-/i/-/p/ = tip!
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's put some letter sounds together to make words! We'll start with our new vowel sound /i/. We can make words like "sit" and "rip" and "tip" by putting the sounds together, just like building with blocks!

slides.prompt: Build with moveable alphabet: sit, rim, tip, rip, pit. Sound out each word. Can you read them back?
slides.mascot_explanation: Now you get to be a word builder! Use your little letter pieces to make words like "sit" and "rip" and "tip." Say each sound as you put the letters together, and then try to read the whole word. You can do it!

slides.text: 'You know TWO vowels now — /a/ and /i/! Vowels are in every word.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify /i/ and build CVC words with it?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you learned another vowel today, the 'i'! That means you know /a/ and /i', and those are super important because they help make all the words. You did such a great job building words with 'i'!

parent_notes: The short /i/ sound is often confused with short /e/ by young children. If this happens, exaggerate the sound and compare: '/i/ — igloo, /e/ — egg.' We will introduce /e/ later. With two vowels and six consonants, the child can now build dozens of CVC words. Keep word building playful — let the child experiment with letter combinations, even nonsense words.

title: Number Rods — Rods 6 Through 10 Review
description: Comprehensive review and practice with the full set of number rods 1-10. The child builds the complete stair and practices counting all rods fluently.
instructions:
1. Invite the child to carry all 10 rods to the mat one at a time.
2. Build the complete stair from 1 to 10.
3. Count each rod, touching every segment.
4. Play 'Show me': 'Show me 8!' 'Which rod has 6?'
5. Compare rods: 'Which is longer, 7 or 9? By how much?'
6. Match all sandpaper numerals to the rods.

slides.heading: Number Rods
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this! We're going to play with special colorful blocks today called number rods. These rods help us learn all about numbers, from one all the way up to ten! We're going to build a beautiful rainbow stair with them.

slides.setup_instructions: Clear a large floor space. Have all rods and numerals available.
slides.mascot_explanation: To make our number stair, we need a few things! See these colorful sticks? Those are our number rods, and they come in different sizes. We also have these bumpy numbers – those are called sandpaper numerals, and they help us feel the numbers. And we need a big space on the floor to build our stair, so let's clear a spot!

slides.text: Carry each rod one at a time, starting with rod 1. 'Let's build the complete stair today!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Our first job is to bring all our number rods to our special building spot. We'll pick them up one by one, starting with the shortest one, which is number 1. We're going to make a big, beautiful stair together, so let's get all our rods ready!

slides.text: Arrange all 10 rods in a stair from shortest to longest, left-aligned.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's put our number rods together to make a stair. We put the shortest one on the left, and then the next shortest one right next to it, and so on, until we have a long, colorful stair going up! It looks like a rainbow staircase, doesn't it?

slides.text: Count each rod together, touching every segment. 'One. One-two. One-two-three...' all the way to ten.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is a super fun part! We get to count each little block in every rod. We'll touch each tiny square and say the numbers together, like "one," then "one, two," then "one, two, three," all the way to the longest rod that has ten!

slides.text: Place each sandpaper numeral next to its matching rod. 'The symbol 7 goes next to the rod with seven.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Remember those bumpy numbers we found? Now we get to match them to our rods! We'll put the number '1' with the shortest rod, the number '2' with the next rod, and keep going until we match all the numbers to their right rod. It's like putting puzzle pieces together!

slides.prompt: Play 'Show Me' with all 10 rods. Then compare: 'How many more does 9 have than 6?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's play a game! I'll say a number, and you show me the rod that matches it. Then, I'll ask you which rod is longer or shorter, like asking "How many more blocks does the big rod have than the little rod?" It's a fun way to see how numbers grow!

slides.text: Return all rods carefully. 'You can count all the way to 10 with the rods!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child build the complete stair, count each rod, and match numerals 1-10?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did such a great job building our number stair and learning all about the rods! You can count all the way to ten now, and you know which rod goes with which number. The coolest part was seeing our big, beautiful rainbow stair all finished!

parent_notes: By week 5, the child should be developing fluency with rods 1-10. If any numbers are still uncertain, spend extra time on those. The comparison questions ('How many more does 9 have than 6?') build early subtraction thinking. Don't name it subtraction yet — just let the child discover the relationship physically by comparing rod lengths.

title: Rough and Smooth Boards — Introduction
description: The child traces surfaces of varying textures with fingertips, developing tactile discrimination and refining the sense of touch. This classic Montessori sensorial material isolates the tactile sense and prepares the hand for writing.
instructions:
1. Invite the child to the lesson. Wash and dry hands together — clean, slightly damp fingers are more sensitive.
2. Present Rough and Smooth Board Set 1 (one half sandpaper, one half smooth wood).
3. Demonstrate: using the tips of two fingers (index and middle), stroke lightly from rough to smooth. Say 'rough' and 'smooth' as you touch each.
4. Invite the child to feel the difference with their own fingertips.
5. Introduce the second board (alternating rough and smooth strips). Stroke across each strip, naming the texture.
6. Optional: offer a blindfold. 'Can you tell which is rough and which is smooth without looking?'
7. Return the boards to the shelf when finished.
materials_needed: Rough and Smooth Boards (Set 1 — two boards)
Small bowl of water and towel for handwashing

slides.heading: Rough and Smooth
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this! We're going to learn about things that feel rough and things that feel smooth. It's like a special game for our fingers to play!

slides.setup_instructions: Place the boards on a table mat. Have the water bowl and towel ready for handwashing before the lesson.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all the fun things we need for our game! We have special boards, a bowl of water to wash our hands, and a soft towel. We'll use these to help our fingers get really good at feeling.

slides.text: 'Let's wash our hands first — clean fingers can feel better.' Wash and dry hands together.
slides.mascot_explanation: First, let's get our hands super clean and ready for touching! Washing our hands makes them feel extra sensitive so we can feel all the different textures.

slides.text: Present Board 1. Stroke the rough side with two fingertips: 'This feels ROUGH.' Stroke the smooth side: 'This feels SMOOTH.'
slides.mascot_explanation: See this board? Let's use just two fingers to gently rub this side. Ooh, it feels bumpy and scratchy, doesn't it? That's called ROUGH. Now let's try the other side – it feels so soft and slick, that's SMOOTH!

slides.text: Invite the child: 'You try. Touch this side... how does it feel?' Let them discover and name the textures.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the explorer! Can you gently touch this side with your fingertips? Tell me, does it feel rough or smooth? You are so good at feeling!

slides.text: Present Board 2 with alternating strips. Stroke across: 'Rough... smooth... rough... smooth.' The child traces each strip.
slides.mascot_explanation: This board has stripes, like a little path! Let's trace each stripe with our fingers, going from one side to the other. We can feel rough, then smooth, then rough, then smooth again, just like a pattern!

slides.prompt: Close your eyes or put on the blindfold. Can you tell which strip is rough and which is smooth just by touching? Point to a rough one. Now a smooth one!
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's play a super fun game! Close your eyes tight, or we can use this soft blindfold. Now, can you find a rough stripe and a smooth stripe just by feeling? Point to the rough one... now point to the smooth one! You're amazing!

slides.text: 'Your fingers can tell the difference between rough and smooth even without your eyes! That is your sense of TOUCH.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child correctly identify rough and smooth surfaces by touch alone?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay! Your fingers are like super-detectives now! You could feel the difference between rough and smooth even with your eyes closed. That's your amazing sense of touch working hard!

parent_notes: The Rough and Smooth Boards are one of the first sensorial materials in Montessori education. They isolate the tactile sense and build vocabulary for describing what the child feels. Always wash hands before this work — slightly damp fingers heighten sensitivity. Use only the lightest touch with the pads of the index and middle fingers, stroking in one direction (left to right). This same light, controlled finger movement directly prepares the hand for writing. The three-period lesson vocabulary (rough/smooth) follows the pattern: 'This is rough' (naming), 'Show me rough' (recognition), 'What is this?' (recall). If the child wants to explore further, you can gather objects from around the house and sort them into rough and smooth categories.
household_substitutes: Rough and Smooth Boards (Set 1 — two boards)
Small bowl of water and towel for handwashing
preparation_steps: Review the lesson steps. Gather all materials before calling your child to the work area.
control_of_error: Observe the child — can they complete the activity independently?
extension_ideas: Repeat the lesson another day
Let the child show a family member what they learned
Connect this activity to daily life

title: Read-Aloud: The Runaway Bunny by Margaret Wise Brown
description: Reading Margaret Wise Brown's tender story about a little bunny who imagines running away and a mother who promises to always find him. Themes of love, security, independence, and imagination.
instructions:
1. Show the cover. 'This is a bunny. He has an idea — he wants to run away! Let's find out what happens.'
2. Read the first exchange: bunny says he'll become a fish, mother says she'll become a fisherman.
3. Before each new page, pause: 'The bunny wants to become a ___. What do you think his mother will do?'
4. Notice the pattern: full-color paintings alternate with black-and-white drawings.
5. After reading: 'Why do you think the bunny stayed? How did the mother show her love?'
6. Discuss: 'If YOU could become anything, what would you become?'
materials_needed: The Runaway Bunny by Margaret Wise Brown

slides.heading: Read-Aloud
slides.subheading: The Runaway Bunny by Margaret Wise Brown
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! This is the cover of a special book we're going to read together. It's called "The Runaway Bunny," and it's all about a little bunny who has a big idea! Let's find out what happens to him.

slides.setup_instructions: Sit comfortably together. This is a quiet, gentle book — set a calm, cozy tone.
slides.mascot_explanation: For our story time, all we need is this book right here. Let's snuggle up somewhere comfy and cozy, like on the couch or in a big chair. Getting nice and relaxed will help us enjoy our sweet story even more!

slides.text: Cover: 'This little bunny tells his mother he wants to run away. What do you think she says?'
slides.mascot_explanation: See the picture on the cover? It's a little bunny, and he's telling his mommy that he wants to run away. Hmm, I wonder what his mommy will say to that! Let's get ready to find out what happens next.

slides.text: Read slowly. Enjoy the rhythm: 'If you become a fish... I will become a fisherman and I will fish for you.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to read a part where the bunny says he wants to be a fish in the sea. His mommy says she'll become a fisherman to find him! We'll read it slowly so we can hear how the words sound, just like a song.

slides.text: Pause before each transformation. 'He wants to be a rock on a mountain! What will his mother become?' Let the child predict.
slides.mascot_explanation: Before we turn each page, we'll stop and guess! The bunny wants to be a rock on a big mountain this time. What do you think his amazing mommy will turn into to find him? Let's think of some fun ideas!

slides.prompt: If you could turn into anything to run away, what would you be? What would Mama or Papa become to find you? Let's make up our own page of the story!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's our turn to be creative! If you could turn into anything to go on an adventure, what would you be? And what would Mommy or Daddy turn into to find you? Let's pretend we're making a new page for the story!

slides.text: 'The bunny decided to stay and be her little bunny after all. Sometimes the best adventures are right at home.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child retell at least two of the bunny's transformations and the mother's responses?
slides.mascot_explanation: The bunny decided he wanted to stay with his mommy after all. Sometimes, the very best adventures are the ones we have right at home with the people we love. You did a great job listening to the whole story!

parent_notes: The Runaway Bunny is a Montessori-friendly read-aloud because it honors the child's growing desire for independence while reassuring them of unconditional love. The predictable if/then pattern supports emergent literacy. The alternating full-color and black-and-white illustrations are worth discussing — the color pages show the mother's imagined response, adding a layer of visual storytelling. This book pairs beautifully with discussions about feelings, family, and the natural world. Children at this age are beginning to assert independence; this story validates those feelings while providing emotional security.
household_substitutes: The book mentioned in the lesson
preparation_steps: Choose a cozy spot. Preview the book before reading it aloud.
control_of_error: Discussion-based — ask open-ended questions about the story.
extension_ideas: Draw a favorite scene
Retell the story in your own words
Act out a scene together

title: Pink Tower — Extension with Brown Stair
description: Combining the Pink Tower and Brown Stair materials for the first time. The child discovers new building patterns using both materials together.
instructions:
1. Build the Pink Tower on the mat.
2. Beside it, build the Brown Stair.
3. Now the extension: lay the Brown Stair prisms flat and place corresponding Pink Tower cubes at the end of each prism.
4. The cube + prism of the same rank create an interesting visual pattern.
5. Let the child experiment with other combinations.
6. Discuss what they notice about the relationships between the two materials.

slides.heading: Pink Tower Extension
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! We're going to do something super fun today with our blocks. We're going to use the big pink blocks and some special brown blocks together to build amazing things!

slides.setup_instructions: You will need a very large mat or two mats side by side for this work.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's get ready for our building adventure! We need the pink blocks, called the Pink Tower, and the long brown blocks, called the Brown Stair. We also need a big soft rug, like our mat, to build on so our blocks stay safe. Ask a grown-up to help you gather them all!

slides.text: 'Today we are going to use the Pink Tower AND the Brown Stair together! First, build each one.'
slides.mascot_explanation: First, let's build the Pink Tower all by itself, just like we always do. Then, we'll build the Brown Stair right next to it. We're putting them together to make something new and exciting!

slides.text: Lay the Brown Stair prisms flat in a row. Place the matching Pink Tower cube at the end of each prism.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's do something different with the brown blocks. We'll lay them down flat, like long sleeping logs. Then, we'll take the pink blocks and place one at the end of each brown one, like they're holding hands!

slides.text: 'Look! The biggest cube matches the biggest prism. What do you notice about the sizes?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Look closely at this! See how the biggest pink block fits perfectly with the biggest brown block? And the next biggest pink one fits with the next biggest brown one? They match just right!

slides.text: 'Can you find other ways to arrange them together? Build something new!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Can you be a super builder and try putting them together in a new way? Let's see what amazing towers or patterns we can make using both the pink and brown blocks together!

slides.prompt: Experiment! Try building a wall, a train, or a city using both the tower cubes and stair prisms together.
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time to play and explore! Let's use all our blocks to build a cool train, a tall city, or maybe even a castle! We have lots of time to build anything we can imagine.

slides.text: Take apart your creation and return each piece to its shelf — Pink Tower pieces first, then Brown Stair.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child match corresponding pieces and create at least one extension pattern?
slides.mascot_explanation: We did such a great job building! Now, let's carefully put all the pink blocks back first, and then all the brown blocks. You were amazing at matching the pieces and building new things!

parent_notes: Extensions are a hallmark of Montessori education. After the child has mastered each material individually, combining them reveals deeper mathematical relationships. The Pink Tower cubes and Brown Stair prisms share the same dimensional progression — the 5cm Pink Tower cube matches the 5cm x 5cm Brown Stair prism. This is indirect preparation for understanding three-dimensional measurement.

title: Sound Games — Middle Sounds
description: Advancing phonemic awareness by listening for middle sounds in CVC words. The child identifies the vowel sound in the middle of simple words.
instructions:
1. 'We can hear sounds at the beginning, end, and now the MIDDLE of words!'
2. Say 'cat' slowly: /c/-/a/-/t/. 'What sound is in the middle? /a/!'
3. Say 'sit': /s/-/i/-/t/. 'The middle sound is /i/!'
4. Practice with 8-10 CVC words: map, tip, rat, sip, cap, rim, tap, pit.
5. Sort picture cards by middle sound: /a/ words vs /i/ words.
6. This is the hardest sound game — be patient and encouraging.

slides.heading: Sound Games
slides.mascot_explanation: Hi friend! We're going to play a super fun game called Sound Games! Today, we'll become super sound detectives and listen very carefully for the sounds hiding in the middle of words. It's like a secret sound puzzle!

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare picture cards for: cat, hat, map, pan, sit, pin, tip, lip.
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at all these fun pictures! We have cards with pictures like a cat and a pin, and we have special mats to put them on. We need these to help us sort the words by their middle sound, just like putting toys in the right box!

slides.text: 'You can hear beginning sounds and ending sounds. Now let's listen to the MIDDLE sound!'
slides.mascot_explanation: We already know how to hear sounds at the start and end of words, right? Now, we're going to do something extra special: we're going to listen for the sound right in the middle of the word! It's like finding the yummy filling in a cookie!

slides.text: Say 'cat' very slowly: /c/...../a/...../t/. 'The middle sound is /a/!' Exaggerate the middle vowel.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's try this word: "cat." Can you say it with me? /c/...../a/...../t/. Hear that sound in the middle? It's the /a/ sound, like when you say "ahhh"! We're going to listen for that sound in other words.

slides.text: Say 'sit': /s/...../i/...../t/. 'The middle sound is /i/!' Practice with several words.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now let's try "sit." Say it slowly: /s/...../i/...../t/. What sound do you hear in the middle? That's right, it's the /i/ sound! We'll practice listening for this sound too.

slides.text: Show a picture card. Say the word slowly. 'What's in the middle — /a/ or /i/?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the sound detective! I'll show you a picture, and we'll say the word slowly together. You tell me if the middle sound is /a/ like in "cat" or /i/ like in "sit." You can do it!

slides.prompt: Sort the picture cards: /a/ words go on one mat, /i/ words go on the other. Say each word slowly to hear the middle.
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, time to play! We get to take all our picture cards and put them on the right mats. If the word has the /a/ sound in the middle, it goes on the /a/ mat, and if it has the /i/ sound, it goes on the /i/ mat. Listen carefully to each word!

slides.text: 'You can hear beginning, middle, AND ending sounds now! That means you can hear ALL the sounds in a word!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify the middle vowel sound in at least 5 out of 8 CVC words?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! You listened so well and found the middle sounds in all those words! Now you can hear sounds at the beginning, the middle, AND the end of words – that's amazing! You are a super sound detective!

parent_notes: Middle sounds are the hardest for children to isolate. Stretch the word out like a rubber band: 'c-a-a-a-t.' If the child struggles, go back to beginning and ending sounds for reinforcement. Only use /a/ and /i/ for now since those are the vowels the child knows. This skill is critical for spelling — the child must hear all three sounds to write CVC words.

title: Spindle Box — Practice and Quantity Building
description: The child independently works with the Spindle Box, building quantities 0-9 with growing confidence. This practice session follows the Week 3 introduction, focusing on independent work, the concept of zero as 'nothing in the compartment,' and self-correction when the final count does not use all 45 spindles.
instructions:
1. Invite the child to choose the Spindle Box from the shelf.
2. Let the child set up independently: spindles in the basket, box on the mat.
3. Observe as the child fills compartments 0 through 9 without assistance.
4. If the child makes an error, do not correct immediately — let them discover it when spindles run out early or are left over.
5. When finished, ask: 'Did you use all the spindles? Are there any left over?'
6. Extension: use rubber bands to bundle each group before placing in the compartment — this emphasizes quantity as a unit.
7. Return materials to the shelf.

slides.heading: Spindle Box
slides.mascot_explanation: Look! This is our special Spindle Box. We're going to play with it all by ourselves today to practice counting!

slides.setup_instructions: Let the child carry the spindle box and basket of spindles to their workspace. This is their independent work today.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these fun things! We have a box with little rooms, lots of long sticks called spindles, and a mat to keep our work tidy. Ask a grown-up to help you carry them to your special spot.

slides.text: 'You know the Spindle Box now. Today you will fill it all by yourself. Start with zero — remember, what goes in zero?'
slides.mascot_explanation: We know how to use this box! Today, you get to fill it up all by yourself. Remember what goes in the first little room, the one with no number? That's right, nothing at all!

slides.text: Step back and observe. The child counts spindles into each compartment independently. Only intervene if the child asks for help.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the super counter! You get to count the little sticks and put them in each room all by yourself. I'll just watch and cheer you on!

slides.text: When the child finishes, ask: 'Did you use every spindle? Let's count the 9 compartment to check.' If spindles are left over or missing, the child recounts.
slides.mascot_explanation: When you're all done, we'll check your work together. Did you use all the sticks, or are there some left over? We can count the sticks in the last room to see!

slides.text: Extension: 'Let's bundle! Wrap a rubber band around the spindles for each number before placing them in.' This shows quantity as a group.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is a fun extra game! We can use these colorful bands to wrap up the sticks for each number. It's like making a little bundle for each number we count.

slides.prompt: Fill the entire spindle box on your own. When you finish, check: are there any spindles left in the basket? If so, find your mistake and fix it!
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time to fill the box all by yourself! Count carefully and fill up each room. Then, let's see if you used all the sticks – if not, we can find where we made a little oopsie!

slides.text: 'You counted from zero all the way to nine by yourself! Zero is special — it means nothing at all. And nine needs the most spindles.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child fill all compartments independently and self-correct if the count is off?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, you did it! You counted all the way from nothing in zero to lots of sticks in nine, all by yourself! You are such a super counter!

parent_notes: This is a practice session, not an introduction — the child was introduced to the Spindle Box in Week 3. The key Montessori principle here is independent work with built-in error control: if the child miscounts, they will have spindles left over or run out before reaching 9. Resist the urge to correct — let them discover and fix the error. The rubber band extension adds a tactile experience of grouping that prepares for later place value work. The concept of zero continues to develop: it is the only compartment that stays empty, which some children find delightfully strange.
preparation_steps: Review the lesson steps. Gather all materials before calling your child to the work area.
control_of_error: Observe the child — can they complete the activity independently?
extension_ideas: Repeat the lesson another day
Let the child show a family member what they learned
Connect this activity to daily life

title: Continent Study — Africa
description: Introduction to the continent of Africa using the Montessori puzzle map. The child learns to identify Africa on the globe, explores its shape by removing and replacing puzzle pieces, and discovers some of Africa's animals and landscapes.
instructions:
1. Begin at the globe. Point to Africa: 'This is Africa. It is the second-largest continent. What color is it on our globe?'
2. Move to the Puzzle Map of Africa. 'This map shows us the COUNTRIES inside Africa.'
3. Remove all puzzle pieces and place them on the mat.
4. Replace each piece one at a time, naming the country as you place it.
5. Highlight 3-4 well-known countries: Egypt, Kenya, South Africa, Madagascar (island!).
6. Show animal miniatures: 'These animals live in Africa — elephant, lion, giraffe, zebra.'
7. Discuss: 'Africa has deserts, rainforests, savannas, and the longest river — the Nile!'
materials_needed: Animal miniatures (elephant, lion, giraffe, zebra, or similar)
Control map of Africa (labeled, for reference)

slides.heading: Africa
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! It says "Africa" and "Exploring a New Continent." That means we get to go on an adventure to a place far, far away! Let's get ready to learn all about it.

slides.setup_instructions: Place the puzzle map on a large work mat. Have the globe nearby. Lay out the animal miniatures on a small tray.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's see what fun things we need for our adventure! We have a big round ball called a globe, and a special puzzle map of Africa. We also have toy animals that live there, and a mat to put everything on.

slides.text: Start at the globe: 'Find the continent that is colored orange (or whatever color your globe uses). This is AFRICA. It is very, very big!'
slides.mascot_explanation: First, let's look at our big globe! See that big orange shape? That's Africa, the continent we're learning about today. It's super, super big, and we're going to find it together.

slides.text: Move to the puzzle map. Remove 3-4 pieces and name them: 'This piece is Egypt — it has the pyramids! This is Kenya — it has lions and elephants.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's look at this cool puzzle map of Africa. It shows all the different parts, like countries! We're going to take some pieces out and learn their names, like Egypt, where the pyramids are!

slides.text: 'Can you find where this piece goes?' Let the child match pieces by shape. The knobs help with the pincer grip.
slides.mascot_explanation: Can you help me find where this piece fits back into our Africa puzzle? Look at its shape and see if it matches a spot. You can use your little fingers to pick up the pieces!

slides.text: Show animal miniatures: 'These animals all live in Africa. The elephant is the biggest land animal in the world!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Oh, look at these cute animals! This is an elephant, and this is a lion. Guess what? They all live in Africa! Isn't that amazing?

slides.prompt: Take out all the puzzle pieces and put them back! Can you find Egypt? Kenya? Madagascar is special — it is an ISLAND off the coast. Match each animal to the continent.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the explorer! Let's take all the puzzle pieces out and put them back in their special spots. Can you find Egypt and Kenya? And let's see if we can match each animal to where it lives in Africa!

slides.text: 'Africa is a continent full of amazing animals, beautiful landscapes, and many different countries. We will learn more about Africa soon!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child locate Africa on the globe and name at least two countries from the puzzle map?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a great job learning about Africa today! We found it on the globe and even learned some of its country names. Africa is full of so many amazing things, and we'll learn even more next time!

parent_notes: The Montessori puzzle maps are a cornerstone of cultural geography education. Each continent gets its own map with color-coded country pieces and small knobs that develop the pincer grip (the same grip used for writing). At this age, the goal is not memorizing every country but developing a sense of the continent's shape, size, and diversity. Let the child explore freely — some children love removing and replacing all the pieces, while others focus on a few countries that capture their interest. Animal miniatures make the lesson concrete and memorable. If you have books about African animals, landscapes, or cultures, leave them out for the child to explore independently. Madagascar is a wonderful conversation starter — 'A country that is an island!'

title: Painting — Wet-on-Wet Watercolor
description: Introduction to the wet-on-wet watercolor technique. The child wets the paper first, then applies watercolor paint to discover how colors blend and spread.
instructions:
1. Tape watercolor paper to the table.
2. Use a large brush to wet the entire paper with clean water.
3. While the paper is wet, touch a loaded brush of watercolor to the paper.
4. Watch the color spread! 'Look how the paint moves on the wet paper!'
5. Add a second and third color. Watch them blend.
6. Let the painting dry flat.

slides.heading: Watercolor Painting
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! We're going to do some super fun painting today, and it's a special kind called "wet-on-wet." That means we'll paint on paper that's already a little wet, and it makes the colors do magical things!

slides.setup_instructions: Tape paper to the table so it doesn't curl. Put on smock. Fill water cup.
slides.mascot_explanation: To make our painting magic, we need a few things! We have special paper for painting, and a box of colorful paints. We also have big brushes to paint with and a cup for water, and a smock to keep our clothes clean. Ask your grown-up to help you get all these things ready!

slides.text: 'Today we paint with watercolors in a special way. First, we make the paper WET.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Our first step is to get our paper ready for the magic! We're going to make the paper all wet before we even touch our paint. This is how we get ready for the colors to spread and mix in a fun way.

slides.text: Use a big brush with clean water to paint the whole paper. 'Make it nice and shiny wet.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's take our big brush and dip it in the clean water. We're going to paint this brush all over our paper, making it super shiny and wet, like a little puddle. See how it looks all sparkly?

slides.text: Dip brush in blue paint. Touch it to the wet paper. 'Look! The paint spreads by itself! The water carries it.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, now for the really fun part! We'll dip our brush into some blue paint, and then gently touch it to our wet paper. Watch closely! See how the blue paint starts to move and spread all by itself on the wet paper? It's like it's dancing!

slides.text: Add yellow next to the blue. 'What color appears where they meet?' (Green!)
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's try another color, like yellow! We'll dip our brush in yellow paint and touch it to the wet paper, maybe right next to the blue. Look! Where the blue and yellow meet, a brand new color is appearing – it's green!

slides.prompt: Create a wet-on-wet painting using 3-4 colors. Watch how they blend and dance on the wet paper!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the art magician! You can pick three or four colors and touch them to your wet paper. Watch them swirl and blend together all by themselves – it's going to be so beautiful!

slides.text: Leave flat to dry. Clean brushes. 'Wet-on-wet painting is magical — the water does the mixing!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child wet the paper and apply watercolor to create blended effects?
slides.mascot_explanation: We did it! We made a beautiful painting by letting the colors mix on the wet paper. Now we just need to let it dry flat, and then we can clean our brushes. Wasn't it cool how the paint moved and mixed all on its own?

parent_notes: Wet-on-wet watercolor is a staple of Waldorf and Montessori art education. The technique creates dreamy, blended paintings with no pressure for representational art. The child learns about color mixing through direct experience. Use good quality watercolor paper — it handles the water better. Tape all edges down to prevent curling. These paintings make beautiful cards and gifts.
household_substitutes: Cup of water and paper towels
preparation_steps: Cover the work surface. Set out materials in order of use. Demonstrate technique first.
control_of_error: Art is self-expressive — focus on the process, not the product.
extension_ideas: Display the artwork proudly
Try the same subject with a different medium
Look at famous artwork for inspiration

title: Cutting — Introduction to Scissors
description: Introduction to proper scissor use. The child learns the correct grip and practices cutting straight lines on paper. This is indirect preparation for handwriting and develops bilateral coordination.
instructions:
1. Present child-safe scissors and demonstrate the grip: thumb in small hole, fingers in large hole.
2. Show how to open and close the scissors ('the alligator opens and closes its mouth').
3. Demonstrate cutting paper strips: hold paper in one hand, cut with the other.
4. Start with cutting across narrow paper strips (1-inch wide).
5. Progress to cutting along a straight line drawn on paper.
6. Collect cut pieces in a bowl for art projects.

slides.heading: Cutting with Scissors
slides.mascot_explanation: Hi friend! Today we're going to learn how to use scissors. Scissors help us cut paper, which is a super important skill that helps our hands get ready for writing.

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare several 1-inch paper strips. Draw thick straight lines on larger paper for cutting practice.
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at all these fun things we need! We have special scissors that are safe for you, some paper strips to practice with, and paper with a line to follow like a tiny road. We also have a tray and a bowl to keep everything tidy. Can you ask a grown-up to help you find all these things?

slides.text: 'Today we learn to use scissors! Scissors are a tool — we use them carefully.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Today we're going to learn how to use scissors! Scissors are a special tool, and just like any tool, we need to use them very carefully and safely.

slides.text: Show the grip: thumb goes in the small hole, two fingers in the big hole. 'Open — close — open — close.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's learn how to hold the scissors! Put your thumb in the little hole, and your pointer finger and middle finger go in the big hole. See? Now, let's make them open and close like a little mouth! Open... and close!

slides.text: Hold a paper strip with your other hand. One snip cuts across! 'Open the alligator, feed it the paper, snap!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to practice cutting! Hold a paper strip gently with one hand, and use your other hand with the scissors. We'll open the scissors like an alligator's mouth, chomp down on the paper, and snap! One little snip!

slides.text: After mastering strips, try cutting along the drawn line. 'Follow the line like a road.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Once we're good at snipping the strips, we'll try cutting along this line. It's like we're driving a little car on the line, and we want to stay right on the road! We'll open and close our scissors to follow the line.

slides.prompt: Cut 10 paper strips with one snip each. Then try cutting along 3 straight lines. Save your pieces!
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you get to try it all now! Let's snip those paper strips ten times, and then try cutting along three lines. It's okay if it's not perfect, the most important thing is that we are trying and learning!

slides.text: Put scissors down open on the tray. Collect cut pieces. 'Your hands are learning a new skill!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child hold scissors correctly and make snips through paper strips?
slides.mascot_explanation: Great job! Put your scissors down open on the tray so they are safe. Look at all the cool pieces you cut! Your hands are learning a brand new skill today, and that's amazing!

parent_notes: Cutting requires bilateral coordination — each hand does a different job simultaneously. This is hard! Start with narrow strips that require only one snip. Left-handed children need left-handed scissors. Supervise closely at first, but the goal is independent use. Cut pieces can be saved for collage work. Never say 'Be careful!' — instead, demonstrate safe carrying (points down, closed).

title: Word Building — CVC Words with Two Vowels
description: Building CVC words using both known vowels (/a/ and /i/). The child discovers how changing the vowel changes the word entirely.
instructions:
1. Review all letter sounds.
2. Build 'cat' with moveable alphabet.
3. 'What happens if we change the /a/ to /i/?' Remove 'a', put in 'i'. '/c/-/i/-/t/ = cit? That's not a word! Try another.'
4. Build 'mat' → change to 'mit.' Build 'cap' → 'cip.' Build 'rat' → 'rit.'
5. Find the real words: sit, pit, tip, rip, rim, pin, Tim.
6. Match objects to words when possible.

slides.heading: Word Building
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! We're going to play a super fun game with words today. We'll learn how changing just one little letter can make a whole new word, like magic!

slides.setup_instructions: Lay out the moveable alphabet. Ensure multiple copies of a and i are available.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's get our special tools ready for our word-making adventure! We have our letters here, called a moveable alphabet, so we can swap them around. We also have a mat to build on, and some fun toys like a kitty to help us!

slides.text: Quick sound review. Then build 'cat': /c/-/a/-/t/.
slides.mascot_explanation: First, let's remember all our letter sounds – you know them so well! Then, we'll use our special letters to build the word "cat." Can you help me find 'c', then 'a', then 't' to make that word?

slides.text: 'Watch this magic! I'm going to change just ONE sound.' Swap 'a' for 'i': /c/-/i/-/t/. 'It changed!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now for the super exciting part! Watch what happens when we take out the 'a' and put in an 'i'. We'll say the sounds together: /c/-/i/-/t/. Does that sound like a word we know?

slides.text: Build pairs: sat/sit, tap/tip, map/mip, rap/rip. 'Which are real words?'
slides.mascot_explanation: We're going to build some word pairs now. Let's make "sat" and then change it to "sit." We'll do the same for "tap" and "tip." Then, we'll see which ones are real words we can say!

slides.prompt: Build 5 words with /a/ in the middle, then build 5 words with /i/ in the middle. Read each one aloud!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the word builder! Can you make five words that have the 'a' sound in the middle, like "cat"? Then, try making five words with the 'i' sound in the middle, like "sit." Say them out loud when you're done!

slides.text: 'Changing just one sound makes a whole new word! Vowels are powerful little letters.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child build and read CVC words with both /a/ and /i/?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a great job building words today! You learned that changing just one little vowel sound, like from 'a' to 'i', can make a completely new word. That's so powerful!

parent_notes: This 'vowel swap' exercise is a breakthrough moment for many children — they realize that changing one sound changes the entire word. This is the essence of the alphabetic principle. Don't worry if some combinations make nonsense words; the child is exploring how the system works. Real-word recognition comes with practice and exposure.

title: Number Rods — Addition Combinations
description: The child discovers addition by placing two shorter Number Rods end-to-end alongside a longer rod. By matching combined lengths, the child physically sees that 3+2 makes the same length as 5, and 4+1 also makes 5. This concrete introduction to addition uses materials the child already knows well.
instructions:
1. Lay out the Number Rods 1-10 on a large floor mat in staircase formation.
2. Take out the 5-rod. 'This is 5. Let's find TWO rods that, placed together, are the same length as 5.'
3. Demonstrate: place the 4-rod on the mat. Place the 1-rod at its end. Compare to the 5-rod. 'Four and one make five!'
4. Find another combination: 3-rod + 2-rod. Place them end-to-end next to the 5-rod. 'Three and two also make five!'
5. Let the child explore: 'Can you find two rods that make the same length as 6? As 7?'
6. For each combination discovered, say the equation aloud: 'Three and four make seven.'
materials_needed: Floor mat (large enough to lay out all rods)

slides.heading: Number Rods
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at that! Today we're going to play a super fun game with our special Number Rods to learn about something called "addition." It's like a math puzzle where we find out how things fit together!

slides.setup_instructions: Lay the floor mat in an open area. Carry rods one at a time from the shelf and build the staircase: 1 at top, 10 at bottom.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's get ready for our game! We need our colorful Number Rods, which are like long building blocks, and a big, soft mat to play on. Can you help me find them and put the mat down so we have lots of space to work?

slides.text: 'Today we are going to discover something amazing with our Number Rods. Take out the 5-rod and place it on the mat by itself.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, first, let's find the Number Rod that is number 5. It's the one that's red! Put it all by itself on our mat, so we can see how long it is.

slides.text: 'Now take the 4-rod and the 1-rod. Put them end-to-end, right next to the 5-rod. Look — they are the SAME LENGTH! Four and one make five!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's grab the orange rod (that's number 4) and the yellow rod (that's number 1). If we put them right next to each other, like they're holding hands, do they reach the same far as the red 5-rod? Yes, they do! So, 4 and 1 make 5!

slides.text: 'Let's try another. Take the 3-rod and the 2-rod. Put them together. Are they the same as 5? YES! Three and two also make five!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's try another one! Can you find the light green rod (that's number 3) and the purple rod (that's number 2)? Put them together, end-to-end. Look, they are the exact same length as our red 5-rod again! So, 3 and 2 also make 5!

slides.text: 'Your turn! Can you find two rods that make the same length as the 6-rod?' Let the child experiment freely.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be a super finder! Can you pick out two rods that, when you put them together, are exactly the same length as the blue 6-rod? Take your time and see what you can discover!

slides.prompt: Find as many combinations as you can! Which two rods make 7? Which two rods make 8? Lay them side by side to check. How many different ways can you make 10?
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the best part! Let's play detective and find secret combinations. How many different ways can you find two rods that fit together perfectly to make the length of the 7-rod? Then, let's try to make the 8-rod and even the 10-rod!

slides.text: 'You discovered ADDITION today! When we put two numbers together, we get a bigger number. Four and one is five. Three and two is five. We call this adding!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child find at least two different addition combinations for a given rod (e.g., two ways to make 5 or 6)?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You discovered "addition" today! That means when we put two numbers together, like 4 and 1, they make a bigger number, like 5. You are such a smart helper, and you found so many ways to make numbers!

parent_notes: This is the Montessori introduction to addition, and it is beautifully concrete. The child physically sees and feels that 3+2 is the same length as 5. There is no memorization — only discovery. The Number Rods provide built-in error control: if the combination is wrong, the lengths will not match. Let the child explore freely and celebrate each discovery. Do NOT introduce the + symbol or written equations yet — this is purely sensorial understanding. Some combinations to explore: 5 = 4+1, 3+2; 6 = 5+1, 4+2, 3+3; 7 = 6+1, 5+2, 4+3; 10 = 9+1, 8+2, 7+3, 6+4, 5+5. The commutative property (3+2 = 2+3) will emerge naturally as the child experiments.
household_substitutes: Floor mat (large enough to lay out all rods)
preparation_steps: Review the lesson steps. Gather all materials before calling your child to the work area.
control_of_error: Observe the child — can they complete the activity independently?
extension_ideas: Repeat the lesson another day
Let the child show a family member what they learned
Connect this activity to daily life

title: Grace and Courtesy — Greeting Visitors
description: Practicing how to greet a visitor at the door. The child learns eye contact, a firm handshake, and polite phrases — real-world social skills.
instructions:
1. 'When someone comes to visit, we greet them. Let me show you how.'
2. Demonstrate: stand up, walk to the door, make eye contact, smile.
3. Say: 'Hello! Welcome to our home.' Offer a handshake.
4. Role-play: parent goes outside and knocks. Child answers and greets.
5. Practice different scenarios: greeting a friend, a grandparent, a delivery person.
6. Add: 'May I take your coat?' or 'Would you like something to drink?'

slides.heading: Grace and Courtesy
slides.mascot_explanation: Look! This is our special lesson about being super polite when someone visits our house. We call it "Grace and Courtesy," which means being kind and showing good manners!

items: No special materials — just a door and practice!
slides.setup_instructions: Clear the entryway so the child can practice walking to the door.
slides.mascot_explanation: We don't need any special toys for this lesson, just our door and our amazing selves! We do need a clear space so we can walk to the door and welcome our friends and family.

slides.text: 'When someone comes to our home, we welcome them. Let me show you what to do.'
slides.mascot_explanation: When someone comes to our door, it's like a little surprise! This step tells us that it's our job to be ready to say hello and make them feel happy they came to visit.

slides.text: Model: stand up straight, walk to the door, open it. 'Hello! Welcome to our home.' Smile and look at their eyes.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's pretend! We stand up tall, walk to the door, and open it with a big smile. Then we say a friendly "Hello! Welcome to our home!" and look right at them, just like this!

slides.text: 'Now we shake hands.' Show a gentle but firm handshake. 'My name is ___. It's nice to see you.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This part is fun – we get to shake hands! We hold their hand gently but firmly, and say our name and how nice it is to see them. It's like a special hello hug with our hands!

slides.prompt: Role-play! Parent goes outside and knocks. Child opens the door and greets them. Switch roles! Practice 3-4 times.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's play a game! I'll go outside and knock, and you can be the one to open the door and say hello just like we practiced. Then we can switch and you can pretend to be the visitor!

slides.text: 'You greet visitors so well! Next time someone comes over, you can answer the door.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child greet someone with eye contact, a greeting phrase, and a handshake?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did such a great job greeting visitors today! You remembered to smile, say hello, and shake hands. Next time someone comes, you'll be the best greeter ever!

parent_notes: Grace and Courtesy lessons are unique to Montessori. They teach social skills explicitly through role-play rather than expecting children to absorb them. Keep the practice lighthearted — silly scenarios are fine (greeting a dinosaur visitor!). These skills give children confidence in real social situations. Practice before actual events: 'Remember, Grandma is coming today. How will you greet her?'
household_substitutes: No materials needed — this is a role-play and discussion lesson
preparation_steps: Think of scenarios to role-play. Keep it playful and positive.
control_of_error: Practice in real situations throughout the day.
extension_ideas: Role-play at a pretend restaurant
Write thank-you notes
Practice with stuffed animals or dolls

title: Nursery Rhymes — Hey Diddle Diddle & Little Miss Muffet
description: Learning two more classic nursery rhymes with dramatic play. Building the rhyme repertoire and phonological awareness.
instructions:
1. Teach 'Hey Diddle Diddle' — act out each silly scene (cow jumping, dish running).
2. Repeat line by line, child echoes.
3. Recite together 3 times.
4. Teach 'Little Miss Muffet.' Discuss: 'What are curds and whey?' (It's like cottage cheese!)
5. Act it out: sit on a 'tuffet,' pretend a spider comes, jump away!
6. Review all previously learned rhymes.
materials_needed: Optional: toy spider for acting out

slides.heading: Nursery Rhymes
slides.subheading: Hey Diddle Diddle & Little Miss Muffet
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! We're going to learn some super fun songs called nursery rhymes today. We'll sing about a funny cat playing music and a little girl who meets a spider!

slides.setup_instructions: Sit face to face for echoing.
slides.mascot_explanation: These are some fun things that can help us with our rhymes! See this book? It has pictures for our songs, and this little spider toy can help us pretend. We'll sit close together to sing and copy each other.

slides.text: 'Hey diddle diddle, the cat and the fiddle...' Act out each character. 'The cow jumped over the MOON!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's sing a silly song called "Hey Diddle Diddle"! We'll pretend the cow is jumping way, way up high over the moon! Can you jump like a cow?

slides.text: Echo each line. Child repeats. Then recite the whole rhyme together.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, I'll sing a line, and you sing it right back to me, like we're singing a song together! Then we'll sing the whole funny rhyme all by ourselves.

slides.text: 'Little Miss Muffet sat on a tuffet...' Explain: a tuffet is a small stool. Curds and whey is like cottage cheese!
slides.mascot_explanation: This next song is about Little Miss Muffet! She sat on a little seat called a tuffet, and she ate some yummy curds and whey, which is like a yummy snack.

slides.prompt: Act out Little Miss Muffet: sit down, pretend to eat, then — SPIDER! Jump up and run away! Do it 3 times.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's pretend to be Little Miss Muffet! We'll sit down like she did, pretend to eat our snack, and then... YIKES! A spider! We have to jump up super fast and run away! Let's do it three times, it's so much fun!

slides.text: 'You know EIGHT nursery rhymes now! Can you remember all of them?'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child recite most of each new rhyme?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! We learned two new rhymes today, and that means you know EIGHT rhymes now! That's so many! Can you sing them all for me? You were so good at jumping away from the spider!

parent_notes: Nursery rhymes with unusual vocabulary (tuffet, curds, whey, diddle) expand the child's language naturally. Don't skip unfamiliar words — explain them briefly and move on. The silliness of these rhymes (a cow jumping over the moon!) delights children and makes the words memorable. Acting them out adds physical memory to verbal memory.
household_substitutes: The book mentioned in the lesson
preparation_steps: Choose a cozy spot. Preview the book before reading it aloud.
control_of_error: Discussion-based — ask open-ended questions about the story.
extension_ideas: Draw a favorite scene
Retell the story in your own words
Act out a scene together

title: Knobbed Cylinders — Block 4 and Two-Block Combinations
description: Introduction to Block 4 of the knobbed cylinders (height increases as diameter decreases). Then combining two blocks for a more challenging discrimination exercise.
instructions:
1. Present Block 4: cylinders vary in both height AND diameter, but inversely.
2. The tallest cylinder is the thinnest; the shortest is the thickest.
3. Remove, scatter, and replace.
4. Combine Blocks 1 and 4: scatter all 20 cylinders from both blocks.
5. The child must determine which cylinder belongs to which block.
6. Replace all cylinders in both blocks.

slides.heading: Knobbed Cylinders
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this fun name! Today, we're going to play with special blocks that have little knobs on top, and we'll even mix two of them together for an extra challenge.

slides.setup_instructions: Place Block 4 on the table first. Keep Block 1 nearby.
slides.mascot_explanation: We need our special knobbed cylinder blocks! See this one? It has cylinders that get shorter as they get fatter. We'll put this one on the table first, and keep the other one close by for later.

slides.text: 'Block 4 is the trickiest! Look — the tall ones are thin and the short ones are thick.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This block is a little tricky! See how the tallest ones are skinny, and the shortest ones are nice and fat? We need to look very carefully at how they change.

slides.text: Remove all cylinders, scatter. Replace each one. Use visual comparison and trial-and-error.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's take all the little pieces out and mix them up! We'll put them back in their special spots, looking closely to see which one fits where. It's like a fun puzzle!

slides.text: 'Now for a BIG challenge! Let's mix two blocks together.' Scatter cylinders from Blocks 1 and 4.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, get ready for a super big challenge! We're going to take pieces from two different blocks and mix them all up together. It's going to be a big puzzle!

slides.text: 'Twenty cylinders! Sort them back into the right blocks and the right holes.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at all these pieces! We have to be super detectives and figure out which piece goes with which block. We'll put them back in their right homes.

slides.prompt: Complete the two-block challenge! Take your time — compare carefully before placing each cylinder.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to do the big puzzle all by ourselves! Take your time, look very carefully at each piece, and try to put them in the right places. You can do it!

slides.text: 'You solved the two-block puzzle! Your eyes are becoming very sharp.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child complete Block 4 alone and attempt the two-block combination?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You solved the super tricky puzzle with all the pieces. Your eyes are so smart for seeing all the differences!

parent_notes: Block 4 is the most complex single block because the dimensions change inversely — as one increases, the other decreases. The two-block combination is a significant challenge requiring careful visual discrimination. Don't help unless the child is truly frustrated. Errors are self-correcting: if a cylinder doesn't fit, it goes somewhere else. This develops problem-solving and patience.

title: Metal Insets — Oval and Curvilinear Triangle
description: Metal inset work with the oval and curvilinear triangle shapes. The child continues building pencil control with more complex curves.
instructions:
1. Present the oval metal inset.
2. Trace the frame, trace the inset, fill with parallel lines.
3. Compare to the circle: 'The oval is stretched like an egg!'
4. Present the curvilinear triangle.
5. Trace and fill. Notice: it has three curved sides.
6. Display both completed designs.

slides.heading: Metal Insets
slides.mascot_explanation: Look! Today we're going to play with some special shapes called metal insets. We'll be working with a shape that looks like a stretched circle, and another shape that's like a wobbly triangle!

slides.setup_instructions: Let the child choose colors. Have enough paper for multiple attempts.
slides.mascot_explanation: To make our shapes beautiful, we need a few things! We have our oval shape and our curvy triangle shape, some nice paper, and lots of colorful pencils. You get to pick which colors you want to use!

slides.text: 'The oval looks like a stretched circle — like an egg shape!' Trace the frame with color 1.
slides.mascot_explanation: First, let's look at this oval shape. It's like a circle that got a little bit stretched out, just like an egg! We're going to trace around the outside of this shape with one of your colors.

slides.text: Trace the inset with color 2. Fill with parallel lines in color 3. Try to stay inside the lines.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's trace the inside part of the oval with a different color. Then, we'll fill the whole oval with lines, like drawing stripes! Try to keep your lines going the same way and stay inside the shape.

slides.text: 'Now the curvilinear triangle — three curved sides! It's like a triangle made of arcs.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Next, we have a new shape called a curvilinear triangle. It looks a little like a triangle, but all its sides are curved, like a smile! Isn't that neat?

slides.text: Trace and fill the curvilinear triangle. Notice how different the filling patterns look in curved shapes.
slides.mascot_explanation: We'll trace this curvy triangle just like we did the oval, and then fill it up with lines too. See how the lines look a little different when they go inside these curved sides?

slides.prompt: Make one design with each shape. Try different line directions: horizontal for one, diagonal for the other.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to create! You get to trace and fill both the oval and the curvy triangle. Try drawing your stripes going straight across for one, and then maybe slanted for the other one!

slides.text: Display your designs. 'Your pencil control is getting better with every inset!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child trace both shapes and fill with reasonably parallel lines?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at your amazing pictures! You did such a super job tracing and filling in all those lines. Your hands are getting so good at drawing these tricky shapes!

parent_notes: Curved shapes are harder to trace and fill than straight-sided ones. The oval and curvilinear triangle challenge the child to make smooth, controlled curves — excellent preparation for cursive letter formation. If the child's lines go outside the boundary, that's normal and will improve with practice. Focus on the process, not perfection.

title: Cards and Counters — Practice and Odd/Even Discovery
description: Practicing cards and counters layout while discovering odd and even number patterns through the arrangement of counters.
instructions:
1. Lay out number cards 1-10 in order on the mat.
2. Show the basket of 55 counters (small discs or buttons).
3. Under card 1, place 1 counter in the center.
4. Under card 2, place 2 counters in a column of pairs.
5. Continue through 10, always placing in pairs (one left, one right).
6. Odd numbers will have one counter 'left over' without a partner.

slides.heading: Cards and Counters
slides.subheading: Cards and Counters — Practice and Odd/Even Discovery
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at that! Today we're going to play a fun game with numbers and little things called counters. We'll learn about numbers and how they can be special, like having a buddy or sometimes being all by themselves!

slides.setup_instructions: Lay number cards in a row across the top of the mat. Place counters in a basket.
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, we have our special things ready! We have these cards with numbers on them, like 1, 2, 3, and so on, all the way to 10. Then we have this big basket full of little counters, like tiny buttons, that we'll use to count with. We also have a big mat to put everything on, so let's get it all ready!

slides.text: Lay out cards 1 through 10 in a row. 'Now we'll put the right number of counters under each card.'
slides.mascot_explanation: First, let's take our number cards and put them down on the mat, one after another, in order. We'll go from 1 all the way to 10, making a nice straight line. This helps us see all the numbers we're going to work with today.

slides.text: Under 1: place one counter in the center. Under 2: place two counters side by side.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's take our little counters and put them under the number cards. Under the number 1, we put just one little counter all by itself. Then, under the number 2, we put two counters, one right next to the other, like they're holding hands!

slides.text: Under 3: two side by side, one in the center below. Under 4: two pairs. Continue through 10.
slides.mascot_explanation: Keep going with your counters! Under the 3, we'll put two counters side-by-side, and then one more counter underneath them. For the number 4, we'll make two pairs, so it looks like two little towers. We'll keep doing this for all the numbers up to 10, making sure our counters are in pairs when we can.

slides.text: 'Look at the bottom of each column. Some have a counter sticking out alone. Those are ODD numbers! The matched ones are EVEN.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Look closely at the bottom of each number's counters! Do you see how some numbers have a single counter all alone, without a friend? Those are called ODD numbers! The numbers that have all their counters in pairs, with no one left out, are called EVEN numbers.

slides.prompt: Run your finger down the center: 1-odd, 2-even, 3-odd, 4-even... What's the pattern? Can you predict if 11 would be odd or even?
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's play a game! Trace your finger down the middle of the counters for each number. See how 1 has one alone? That's odd! See how 2 has a pair? That's even! Let's go all the way to 10 and see if we can guess if the next number, 11, will be odd or even!

slides.text: 'Odd numbers: 1, 3, 5, 7, 9. Even numbers: 2, 4, 6, 8, 10. You discovered a pattern!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child set up cards and counters correctly and identify odd vs even?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You put all the cards and counters in the right spots and found the odd and even numbers. We saw that 1, 3, 5, 7, and 9 are odd because they have one left over, and 2, 4, 6, 8, and 10 are even because they all have pairs. You're so good at finding patterns!

parent_notes: Cards and Counters is the third Montessori math material in sequence (after number rods and spindle box). It introduces odd and even numbers through a visual pattern — odd numbers have a counter 'sticking out' at the bottom. The arrangement in pairs is key; don't let the child place counters randomly. This discovery of odd/even is a child's first encounter with number properties.
preparation_steps: Review the lesson steps. Gather all materials before calling your child to the work area.
control_of_error: Observe the child — can they complete the activity independently?
extension_ideas: Repeat the lesson another day
Let the child show a family member what they learned
Connect this activity to daily life

title: Smelling Bottles — Introduction
description: The child explores the Montessori Smelling Bottles, matching pairs of bottles by scent alone. This classic sensorial material isolates the olfactory sense and develops concentration, discrimination, and vocabulary for describing smells.
instructions:
1. Present two sets of Smelling Bottles (6 pairs) on a tray. One set has red caps, the other has blue caps.
2. Demonstrate: pick up one red-cap bottle, open it, and waft the scent toward your nose (do not sniff directly). 'This smells like... lemon! It is fresh and sharp.'
3. Pick up a blue-cap bottle, waft and smell. 'Does this one smell the same? No, this is different.'
4. Try another blue-cap bottle. 'This one matches! Both smell like lemon.'
5. Place the matching pair together.
6. Invite the child to find the remaining matches.
7. Name each scent together: lemon, cinnamon, vanilla, peppermint, coffee, lavender.
materials_needed: Smelling Bottles (set of 6 pairs — red caps and blue caps)

slides.heading: Smelling Bottles
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this fun title slide! It says "Smelling Bottles" and "Matching Scents." That means we're going to use our noses to find things that smell the same!

slides.setup_instructions: Place red-cap bottles on the left side of the tray and blue-cap bottles on the right. If making your own, fill small identical bottles with cotton balls soaked in scents: lemon, cinnamon, vanilla, peppermint, coffee, lavender.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these special bottles! We have some with red tops and some with blue tops, and they're all sitting on a tray. These bottles have yummy or interesting smells inside them, and we need them to play a matching game with our noses. Ask your grown-up to help you get these ready!

slides.text: 'Today we are going to use our sense of SMELL. These bottles have different scents hidden inside.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Today, we get to use our super-powered sense of smell! These cool bottles have secret smells inside, and it’s like a treasure hunt for your nose. We're going to see if we can guess what they are!

slides.text: Demonstrate wafting: open a red-cap bottle, hold it near your nose, and wave your hand over it to draw the scent toward you. 'I can smell... something sweet!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, watch me! I'm going to open one of the red bottles, but I won't sniff it super hard. Instead, I'll wave my hand to bring the smell to my nose, like this. Ooh, this one smells a little bit like something sweet and yummy!

slides.text: Open a blue-cap bottle and waft. 'Does this smell the same? No — this one is different.' Try another blue bottle until you find the match.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's try one of the blue bottles. I'll open it and bring the smell to my nose, just like before. Hmm, does it smell the same as the red one? Nope, this one is different! Let's try another blue one.

slides.text: Place the matching pair together in the center. 'These two are the same — they both smell like cinnamon!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, I found a match! This blue bottle smells just like the red one we smelled before. They both smell like cinnamon! When we find two that smell the same, we put them together.

slides.prompt: Find all the matching pairs! Open a red bottle, smell it carefully, then find its match among the blue bottles. Place each pair together when you find them.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the super smeller! Pick a red bottle, smell it carefully, and then sniff around the blue bottles to find its match. When you find two that smell the same, put them together! You can do it!

slides.text: 'You matched all the scents with your nose! Our sense of smell is very powerful. Can you name the scents you found?'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child correctly match at least 4 of the 6 scent pairs?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a great job matching all the smells with your nose! Our noses are amazing at finding things that smell the same, aren't they? Can you remember any of the smells you found, like sweet cinnamon or fresh lemon?

parent_notes: The Smelling Bottles are part of the Montessori sensorial curriculum and are often overlooked in home settings. They isolate the olfactory sense just as the Rough and Smooth Boards isolate touch. If you do not have the official Montessori bottles, you can easily make your own: use small, identical opaque containers (like film canisters or small jars with cotton balls) and add a few drops of essential oil or a pinch of spice. Good scent choices: lemon, cinnamon, vanilla extract, peppermint, coffee grounds, lavender. Make two of each. The wafting technique (fanning scent toward the nose rather than sniffing directly) is important — it is gentler and mirrors what scientists do in laboratories. Build vocabulary: 'Is this scent sharp or soft? Sweet or spicy? Strong or gentle?' This material develops concentration, discrimination, and the language to describe sensory experiences.
household_substitutes: Smelling Bottles (set of 6 pairs — red caps and blue caps)
preparation_steps: Review the lesson steps. Gather all materials before calling your child to the work area.
control_of_error: Observe the child — can they complete the activity independently?
extension_ideas: Repeat the lesson another day
Let the child show a family member what they learned
Connect this activity to daily life

title: Music — High and Low Sounds
description: Exploring the concept of pitch: high and low sounds. The child experiments with instruments and voice to distinguish between high and low.
instructions:
1. Demonstrate high and low with your voice: high squeaky voice, low rumbly voice.
2. Play a xylophone or keyboard: left side = low notes, right side = high notes.
3. Let the child explore: 'Play a HIGH sound! Now play a LOW sound.'
4. Listen to environmental sounds: bird (high), thunder (low), whistle (high), drum (low).
5. Play 'High or Low': you play a note, child identifies.
6. Move your body: stretch up high for high sounds, crouch low for low sounds.
materials_needed: Optional: recordings of high and low sounds

slides.heading: Music Exploration
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this slide! It's all about exploring music and learning about sounds that go up high and sounds that go down low. We're going to have so much fun making music together!

slides.setup_instructions: Set up the instrument where the child can play freely.
slides.mascot_explanation: For our music adventure today, we need a special instrument that makes lots of different sounds. See this colorful xylophone or keyboard? It has little bars that make high sounds and bigger bars that make low sounds. We might also listen to some fun sounds if we have them ready!

slides.text: 'Sounds can be HIGH like a bird tweet or LOW like a bear growl. Listen!' Demonstrate with your voice.
