slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's listen really closely! Sometimes our voices can make sounds that are super high, like a tiny little bird singing. Other times, our voices can be low and rumbly, like a big sleepy bear. Let's try making a high sound together... and now a low sound!

slides.text: Play the instrument: tap the small bars (high) then the big bars (low). 'Hear the difference?'
slides.mascot_explanation: This part is so cool! We get to play with our instrument. Listen when I tap the small bars – hear how high that sounds? Now listen when I tap the big bars – that's a low sound! Can you hear how different they are?

slides.text: Child plays: 'Find the highest sound you can make. Now the lowest.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, it's your turn to play! Let's see if you can find the highest, squeakiest sound on the instrument. Now, try to find the lowest, rumbly sound. You can do it!

slides.prompt: Play 'High or Low' — I play a note, you tell me if it's high or low. Then you play and I guess! Move your body: up high or down low!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to play a fun game called "High or Low"! I'll play a sound, and you tell me if it's high or low. Then, you play a sound, and I'll guess! When we hear a high sound, let's stretch up super tall, and for a low sound, let's crouch down small.

slides.text: 'You can hear HIGH sounds and LOW sounds. Music is made of sounds moving up and down!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify and produce high versus low sounds?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a fantastic job exploring music today! You learned how to make high sounds and low sounds with your voice and our instrument. Music is all about those amazing sounds going up and down, and you're a super star at hearing them!

parent_notes: After learning loud/soft (dynamics) in week 1, we now explore high/low (pitch). These are the two most fundamental properties of sound. A xylophone is ideal because the child can SEE the size difference that creates pitch difference (small bars = high pitch). Adding body movement (stretching up for high, crouching for low) creates a physical memory of pitch.
household_substitutes: Pots, pans, wooden spoons for rhythm
preparation_steps: Gather sound-making objects. Choose a space where noise is okay.
control_of_error: Can the child repeat a rhythm pattern? Can they keep a steady beat?
extension_ideas: Create a simple song together
Clap rhythm patterns for each other to copy
Listen to different genres and compare

title: Cutting — Straight Lines and Curves
description: Progressing from cutting strips to cutting along straight lines and gentle curves. Building confidence and control with scissors.
instructions:
1. Review proper scissor grip.
2. Practice cutting 5 paper strips (warm-up).
3. Cut along thick straight lines drawn on paper.
4. Introduce gentle curves: draw wavy lines on paper.
5. Show how to turn the paper (not the scissors) when cutting curves.
6. Cut along the curved lines. Save pieces for a collage.
materials_needed: Glue stick and background paper for collage

slides.heading: Cutting Practice
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! Today we get to practice using our scissors to cut! We're going to learn how to cut straight lines and then some curvy, wavy lines too. It's going to be so much fun!

slides.setup_instructions: Draw thick straight lines and wavy/curved lines on separate papers. Use markers so lines are easy to see.
slides.mascot_explanation: We need some special things for our cutting adventure today! See these scissors? They help us cut paper. We also have paper with lines on it, like a road for our scissors to follow. Then, we'll use glue and another piece of paper to make a beautiful picture with all the pieces we cut. Can you ask a grown-up to help you find all these things?

slides.text: Warm up with 5 paper strips — one snip each. 'Good! Your hands remember the grip.'
slides.mascot_explanation: First, let's warm up our hands and our scissors! We have some skinny paper strips, and we're just going to snip them into pieces. Open your scissors, close them, open, close! This helps your hand remember how to hold the scissors just right.

slides.text: Now cut along the straight line. 'Open, close, open, close — follow the line like a path.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to cut on a real line! See this thick straight line? We want to pretend our scissors are a little car driving on a road. Open your scissors, close them, open, close, and try to follow that line all the way to the end. You're doing so great!

slides.text: 'Curves are trickier! The secret: turn the PAPER, not the scissors.' Show how to rotate the paper with the other hand.
slides.mascot_explanation: Cutting on curves is a little different, and it's a fun trick! When we cut a wavy line, we don't turn our scissors. Instead, we turn the *paper* with our other hand, like we're steering a boat. Watch how we turn the paper slowly as we cut.

slides.text: Cut along a gentle wavy line. 'Slow and steady — you're doing it!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's try cutting along this wavy line now! Remember our trick: turn the paper, not the scissors. Go nice and slow, open, close, open, close, and follow that wiggly line. You are doing such a wonderful job!

slides.prompt: Cut out 3 straight pieces and 3 curved pieces. Arrange them into a collage and glue them down!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to make a beautiful picture! We're going to cut out some straight pieces and some curvy pieces. After we cut them, we can put them all together like a puzzle on our big paper and use glue to stick them down. Let's see what amazing art we can create!

slides.text: Clean up scraps. Display the collage. 'Your cutting is improving so much!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child cut along straight lines and attempt curves?
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at all the wonderful pieces you cut! We made straight lines and even those tricky curves. You did such a super job cutting today, and your picture looks amazing! Let's find a special spot to hang it up.

parent_notes: The key instruction for curves is to turn the paper, not the scissors. This is a coordination milestone. If the child struggles with curves, make wider, gentler curves first and gradually tighten them over the weeks. The collage combines cutting with composition — the child decides where to place pieces and creates something original from cut shapes.
household_substitutes: Glue stick and background paper for collage
preparation_steps: Review the lesson steps. Gather all materials before calling your child to the work area.
control_of_error: Observe the child — can they complete the activity independently?
extension_ideas: Repeat the lesson another day
Let the child show a family member what they learned
Connect this activity to daily life

title: Sandpaper Letters — Review Game and Sand Tray Writing
description: A comprehensive review of all 8 sandpaper letters through games and sand tray writing. Making the review fun and active.
instructions:
1. Spread all 8 sandpaper letters on the floor.
2. Play 'Jump to It': say a sound, child jumps to that letter.
3. Play 'Trace and Race': how many letters can the child trace in one minute?
4. Sand tray writing: say a word, the child writes each letter in the sand tray.
5. Try writing simple CVC words in sand: 'sat,' 'tip,' 'mat,' 'rip.'
6. Celebrate all the sounds the child knows.
materials_needed: All 8 sandpaper letters (s, m, a, t, p, c, r, i)

slides.heading: Sandpaper Letters
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! Today we get to play a super fun game with our special letters. We are going to have a review day and play games to help us remember them all!

slides.setup_instructions: Spread the letters on the floor with space around each. Have the sand tray on the table.
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, it's time to get our special things ready for our games! We have our bumpy sandpaper letters, and a tray full of soft sand for writing. Ask a grown-up to help you spread the letters out on the floor and get the sand tray ready for some fun writing!

slides.text: 'Let's play a game! I say a sound, and you JUMP to that letter. Ready? /t/!' Child jumps to 't'.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's play a jumping game! I'll make a sound, and you have to be super fast and jump to the letter that makes that sound. Listen carefully: /t/! Where is the letter that makes the /t/ sound? Go ahead and jump to it!

slides.text: Trace and Race: 'How many letters can you trace and say in one minute? Ready, set, GO!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to play "Trace and Race"! We'll see how many letters you can trace with your finger and say the sound for in just one minute. Ready, set, GO! See how many you can do!

slides.text: Sand tray: 'I'm going to say a word. You write each sound in the sand.'
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time to use our magic sand tray! I'm going to say a word, and you get to be a super writer and write each letter sound in the sand. It's like drawing with your finger in soft sand!

slides.text: 'Write sat: /s/...write s.../a/...write a.../t/...write t. You wrote SAT!'
slides.mascot_explanation: We're going to write the word "sat." First, let's write the /s/ sound, then the /a/ sound, and then the /t/ sound. Look, you just wrote the word SAT in the sand! You're such a good writer!

slides.prompt: Write these words in the sand tray: sat, tip, mat, rip, sip, cap. Shake the tray to erase between words!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the teacher and write some words all by yourself in the sand! Can you write "sat," "tip," "mat," and "rip"? When you're done with a word, just shake the tray like this to make it disappear and get ready for the next word!

slides.text: 'You know 8 sounds and you can WRITE words! That's amazing!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify all 8 sounds and write CVC words in sand?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You know so many letter sounds, and you are a fantastic writer! You can even write whole words in the sand, which is amazing! Give yourself a big clap for being such a super learner!

parent_notes: Review should feel like a game, not a test. 'Jump to It' adds movement and energy. Sand tray writing of whole words is a significant step — the child is encoding (spelling) rather than just decoding (reading). If the child struggles with a particular letter, make a note and give it extra practice during the week. Writing words in sand is less intimidating than writing on paper.

title: Memory Game — Quantities 1-10
description: A Montessori memory game where the child is given a number, walks across the room, gathers that quantity of objects, and brings them back. Develops number sense and working memory.
instructions:
1. Set up a mat on one side of the room with small objects (beads, buttons, acorns).
2. The child stands at the other side with numeral cards.
3. Child draws a numeral card (e.g., 7).
4. Child walks to the object mat and counts out 7 objects into their hand.
5. Walks back. Together, verify: count the objects. Does it match the card?
6. Play multiple rounds. Mix up the cards.
materials_needed: 50+ small objects (beads, buttons, or natural objects)

slides.heading: The Memory Game
slides.mascot_explanation: Hi friend! This is our super fun game called the Memory Game, and we're going to use our brains to remember numbers and count things. It's like a treasure hunt for numbers!

slides.setup_instructions: Place objects on a mat at one end of the room. Numeral cards stay at the other end.
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at all these things we need for our game! We have special number cards, and lots of little treasures like beads and acorns. We also have two special mats and a little basket to carry our treasures. Ask your grown-up to help you find everything and put it all in its place!

slides.text: 'This is the Memory Game! You pick a number card, walk across the room, and bring back that many objects.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, here's how we play! First, you'll pick a secret number card, then you'll walk all the way across the room to find the treasures. Your job is to bring back the exact same number of treasures as the number on your card!

slides.text: Demonstrate: draw card 4. Walk to the mat. Count out 4 objects. Carry them back. 'Let's check — 1, 2, 3, 4. I got it right!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Watch me! I picked the number four card. Now I'm going to walk over to the treasures and carefully count out four of them. See? One, two, three, four! Now I'll bring them back to check. Yay, I got it right!

slides.text: Child draws a card. 'Remember your number!' Walk, count, carry, check.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn! Take a deep breath and pick a number card. Remember your number super well, walk over to the treasures, count them out just like I did, and bring them back. We'll count them together to make sure!

slides.prompt: Play 5 rounds of the Memory Game. Can you get the right number every time? Try challenging numbers like 8 or 9!
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's play some more rounds of our game! We'll try picking different numbers, maybe even a tricky one like eight or nine. You can do it, just remember your number and count carefully!

slides.text: 'You remembered your numbers and counted accurately. Great memory and great counting!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child accurately gather the correct quantity from memory for numbers 1-10?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did such a great job playing the Memory Game! You remembered your numbers and counted so perfectly every time. Your memory is like a super sponge, soaking up all those numbers!

parent_notes: The Memory Game is a beloved Montessori activity because it combines movement with math. Walking across the room means the child must hold the number in working memory — they can't look at the card while counting. This builds mental number sense rather than rote counting. If the child consistently gets a particular number wrong, that number needs more practice with concrete materials.

title: Continent Globe — Introduction
description: Introduction to the Montessori Continent Globe (colored globe). The child reviews the seven continents using the color-coded globe and begins matching continents to their colors.
instructions:
1. Present the colored continent globe.
2. Review: spin and point to each continent. Name it.
3. Montessori colors: North America (orange), South America (pink), Europe (red), Asia (yellow), Africa (green), Australia/Oceania (brown), Antarctica (white).
4. Play color matching: hold up a color card, child finds that continent on the globe.
5. Focus on: 'Where do we live? Where do our food, stories, or music come from?'
6. Begin a 'Continent Book': one page per continent with a tracing and the name.

slides.heading: The Continent Globe
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this big ball! It's called a globe, and it shows us all the different parts of our world, like where we live! We're going to learn all about the special colors for each big piece of land.

slides.setup_instructions: Place the globe on the table. Prepare color cards matching: orange, pink, red, yellow, green, brown, white.
slides.mascot_explanation: We need a few fun things to play with today! We have our colorful globe, some bright color cards, and a special book we'll make. Ask a grown-up to help you gather these so we can start our adventure!

slides.text: 'Each continent on this globe has its own special color. Let's learn them!'
slides.mascot_explanation: This globe has special colors for each giant land we call a continent. Learning their colors will help us know where they are in the big, wide world. Let's get ready to discover them!

slides.text: Point to each continent. 'North America is ORANGE. South America is PINK. Europe is RED...'
slides.mascot_explanation: See this big land? It's called North America, and it's the color orange! And this one is South America, and it's pink. We'll learn all the colors for all the continents together.

slides.text: Hold up a color card: 'YELLOW! Which continent is yellow?' Child finds Asia on the globe.
slides.mascot_explanation: Look, I have a yellow card! Can you find the continent that is yellow on our globe? That's right, it's Asia! You're so good at finding the colors!

slides.prompt: Start your Continent Book: trace or draw each continent on a page and color it the right Montessori color. Write the name.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to make our own special book about the continents. We'll draw each one and color it the right color, just like we learned. Then, we'll write its name so we remember it!

slides.text: 'Seven continents, seven colors! We'll learn about each continent's special things in the weeks to come.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child match at least 5 of the 7 continent colors?
slides.mascot_explanation: We did it! We learned all about the seven continents and their special colors! It's amazing how many different places there are in the world, and we'll learn even more cool things about them soon.

parent_notes: The Montessori color-coding of continents is consistent across all Montessori geography materials worldwide. Learning the colors helps children quickly identify continents on maps, puzzle maps, and flags. The Continent Book is a long-term project — each week you can add facts, pictures, or drawings about a specific continent. This becomes a treasured reference.

title: Read-Aloud: If You Give a Mouse a Cookie by Laura Numeroff
description: Reading Laura Numeroff's playful circular story about a mouse whose one request leads to an endless chain of demands. The story teaches cause and effect, sequencing, and the humor of a chain reaction that comes full circle.
instructions:
1. Show the cover. 'This is a mouse, and someone is giving him a cookie! What do you think will happen?'
2. Read the first few pages. Establish the pattern: giving the mouse one thing leads him to want another.
3. At each new request, pause: 'He got the cookie. Now what does he want? A glass of milk! One thing leads to another.'
4. As the story continues, ask: 'What do you think he will want next?'
5. When the story circles back to the cookie: 'We are back at the beginning! It is a CIRCLE story.'
6. Retell together: 'First the cookie, then the milk, then...'
materials_needed: If You Give a Mouse a Cookie by Laura Numeroff

slides.heading: Read-Aloud
slides.subheading: If You Give a Mouse a Cookie by Laura Numeroff
slides.mascot_explanation: Look! This is the cover of our special book for today! It's called "If You Give a Mouse a Cookie." See the little mouse? Someone is giving him a yummy cookie. I wonder what will happen next!

items: If You Give a Mouse a Cookie book
slides.setup_instructions: Sit comfortably together. This is a fun, lively book — enjoy the silliness of the mouse's escalating demands!
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, we get to read a book together! This is the book we need for our story time. Let's find a comfy spot to sit so we can look at all the pictures and laugh with the silly mouse.

slides.text: Cover: 'Look at this mouse. Someone is about to give him a cookie. Do you think one cookie will be enough?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at the picture! It's a little mouse, and he's getting a cookie. Do you think he'll just eat that one cookie and be happy? Or maybe he'll want something else after that? Let's see!

slides.text: Read with energy. Emphasize the chain: 'If you give him a cookie, he will want a glass of MILK.' The child will start to see the pattern.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now the mouse got his cookie, and he wants a big glass of milk to go with it! See how one thing makes him want another thing? It's like when you finish your juice, and then you want more water!

slides.text: Pause before each new request: 'He looked in the mirror and noticed his hair needs a trim. What will he want now?' Let the child predict.
slides.mascot_explanation: Oh no, the mouse is looking in the mirror and his hair needs a trim! What do you think he wants now? Hmm, maybe he wants some scissors? What do *you* think he'll ask for next?

slides.prompt: The story goes in a circle! Can you remember the chain? Cookie leads to milk, milk leads to... what? How many things did the mouse ask for? Let's count on our fingers!
slides.mascot_explanation: This mouse is so silly! He asked for a cookie, then milk, then a haircut... what else did he ask for? Let's try to remember all the things he wanted in order. Can we count how many things he asked for on our fingers?

slides.text: 'The mouse ended up right back at the cookie! This is called a circular story — it goes round and round. One thing always leads to another!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain that the story goes in a circle and recall at least four items in the chain?
slides.mascot_explanation: We finished our story! Wasn't that funny? The mouse ended up wanting another cookie, right where we started! That means it's a circle story, it goes round and round, just like a wheel on a toy car.

parent_notes: This book is a delightful introduction to cause and effect (if/then thinking) and circular narrative structure. Children find the mouse's escalating demands hilarious, which makes it highly engaging. The circular ending is a sophisticated literary concept that even young children can grasp concretely: the story starts and ends in the same place. After reading, you can play a 'chain game' at home: 'If I give you a crayon, what would you want next? And then what?' This extends the cause-and-effect thinking. Laura Numeroff wrote many 'If You Give...' books — if your child loves this one, the series provides wonderful repeated exposure to the same narrative structure.
household_substitutes: The book mentioned in the lesson
preparation_steps: Choose a cozy spot. Preview the book before reading it aloud.
control_of_error: Discussion-based — ask open-ended questions about the story.
extension_ideas: Draw a favorite scene
Retell the story in your own words
Act out a scene together
